choices.C: The server administrator created user accounts cloning the wrong user ID, and the accounts should be removed from administrators and placed in an employee group.
choices.A: The Windows Active Directory domain controller has not completed synchronization, and should force the domain controller to sync.
choices.D: The naming scheme allows for too many variations, and the account naming convention should be updates to enforce organizational policies.
choices.B: The server has been compromised and should be removed from the network and cleaned before reintroducing it to the network.

questions.question_text: A security incident has been created after noticing unusual behavior from a Windows domain controller. The server administrator has discovered that a user logged in to the server with elevated permissions, but the user's account does not follow the standard corporate naming scheme. There are also several other accounts in the administrators group that do not follow this naming scheme. Which of the following is the possible cause for this behavior and the BEST remediation step?

discussion.content:
Anybody pick C? Should be Windows admin put the user name to local administrators group
and could not follow the AD DC naming convention.

Answer D after multiple reads of the question and reading the great other comments. Question does not specify a compromise/event, just behavior/incident to investigate. The only issue with the elevated permission login at this time is that the analyst (you/us) doesn't recognize the naming scheme of the account. Also if it's a Windows Domain Controller then there are NO local accounts on the Server itself, only Domain Accounts. Windows Member Servers can have local accounts; but not Domain Controllers. If Admin accounts are compromised, taking this Server offline would not help with an Admin account breach in this situation...only to kick the bad actor off this one server. Ultimately there's no security event here, just unrecognized user naming convention.
The user's account not following the standard corporate naming scheme implies that there's already a standard in place so should be B?
I'm going with B on this one, albeit the remediate step is insufficient.

comments.content: crap question, re-reading it all.... there is just so little in the question to decide between the answers

I'm still torn with B or D. I want to go with B because there's unusual behavior and accounts created. But D is also a good choice since there are several accounts which do not follow the naming convention. Surely the attacker wants to be discrete so the presence of many accounts not following the naming convention will make the attack noticeable.

discussion.content: implying that there is a followed naming convention... surely its more likely to be B?

comments.content: Agree. There is unusual behavior and accounts created which do not follow the standard naming convention.

choices.A: Configure directory services with a federation provider to manage accounts.
choices.D: Configure user accounts for self-service account management.
choices.B: Create a group policy to extend the default system lockout period.
choices.C: Configure a web browser to cache the user credentials.

questions.question_text: A company decides to move three of its business applications to different outsourced cloud providers. After moving the applications, the users report the applications time out too quickly and too much time is spent logging back into the different web-based applications throughout the day. Which of the following should a security architect recommend to improve the end-user experience without lowering the security posture?

discussion.content:
I think should be A.
Because the question says "the users report the applications time out too quickly and too much time is spent logging back INTO THE DIFFERENT WEB-BASED APPLICATIONS throughout the day"
So I guess if we setup Federation, user needs to type credentials just once, and not for every single application.

comments.content: plus, the question says: "Which of the following should a security architect recommend to improve the end-user experience WITHOUT LOWERING THE SECURITY POSTURE?" -> So this one discards to modify GPO increasing timeout value.

discussion.content: GPO only applies to Windows OS so the correct answer which solves the timeout and lengthy login is A since the apps are cloud based.

How would a GPO affect anything on a cloud hosted app??
BS questions
The question is poorly written. The answer should be two A and B.

I think B is incorrect - the application times out quickly and not the system, group policy won't be able to change the application's timeout.
I'm thinking of A?

comments.content: Wouldn't the GPO apply solely to the workstations of the users? The time-out issue might not be resolved, but by using a SSO solution would prevent users from constantly being logged out.
federated identity won't mitigate the time out issue though.... B is the only one that looks to resolve the issue.... pretty poor questions aha
it states "without lowering " so seems like A is only logical choice here

discussion.content:
why not A? 
"# nmap sS 192.168.1.13 p1417" (nmap with TCP SYN scan) should give more information than just displaying the version, right?

https://explainshell.com/explain?cmd=nmap+-sS
https://explainshell.com/explain?cmd=nmap+-sV

comments.content: Is Ss what he ran to get these result displayed in the question?

questions.question_text: A reverse engineer was analyzing malware found on a retailer's network and found code extracting track data in memory. Which of the following threats did the engineer MOST likely uncover?

discussion.content: This question was in the exam :)

choices.B: The administrator should fix smtp (25/tcp). The remote SMTP server is insufficiently protected against relaying. This means spammers might be able to use the company's mail server to send their emails to the world.
choices.A: The administrator should fix dns (53/tcp). BIND "˜NAMED' is an open-source DNS server from ISC.org. The BIND-based NAMED server (or DNS servers) allow remote users to query for version and type information.
choices.E: The administrator should fix general/tcp. The remote host does not discard TCP SYN packets that have the FIN flag set. Depending on the kind of firewall a company is using, an attacker may use this flaw to bypass its rules.
choices.C: The administrator should fix http (80/tcp). An information leak occurs on Apache web servers with the UserDir module enabled, allowing an attacker to enumerate accounts by requesting access to home directories and monitoring the response.
choices.D: The administrator should fix http (80/tcp). The "˜greeting.cgi' script is installed. This CGI has a well-known security flaw that lets anyone execute arbitrary commands with the privileges of the http daemon.

discussion.content: D should be right. Anything related to a command execution/code execution is the MOST critical

Selected Answer: D
D:
D: as it says the scrpt IS installed
B: hacker MAY be able to send emails
Anything RCE is priority so D is the correct answer. Who reviews even these answers?

comments.content: agree with you, RCE comes first.

discussion.content: B seems to imply PII information leak...

comments.content: No it doesn't. Open Relay just allows attackers to route their own mails through your mail server. It doesn't allow attackers to access the actual mails within the company.
I think it is also D

discussion.content:
Why B and not D? What is the criteria here? If we're looking at severity, D is way worse than B:
https://www.acunetix.com/vulnerabilities/web/smtp-open-mail-relay/
https://www.acunetix.com/vulnerabilities/web/php-cgi-remote-code-execution/

Can anyone give me a good - and relevant to CySA+ - explanation why anyone would pick B over D?

questions.question_text: A company has monthly scheduled windows for patching servers and applying configuration changes. Out-of-window changes can be done, but they are discouraged unless absolutely necessary. The systems administrator is reviewing the weekly vulnerability scan report that was just released. Which of the following vulnerabilities should the administrator fix without waiting for the next scheduled change window?
